text: Bottle, sent by SlovakSniper (thanks Pat!), and shared at game night. Very hazy pale yellow with a lively white head. Big juicy tropical fruit flavours, tart/sour, with moderate funk and light grassy notes. Extremely drinkable, really tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 375ml b3 bottle pours semi clear dark reddish orange with a half finger of off-pink foam. Nose and taste have big funk, nice layered notes of wood, dried citrus, apricot, orange zest, light spice, touch of toast malt, oak, berry, wine, slight oud bruin character. Funk, funk, more funk. Finishes with moderate tartness. Very good stuff.

375ml bottle from the brewery (thx, Jonathan S.!). Bottled in December 2016, batch #3. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is barrel, fermented fruits and veggies, bretts, some sweet notes. Taste is similar with some hoppy bitterness. Very nice and refreshing stuff.

750ml bottle pours out golden topped with a white head. Nose is sour funky notes some barrel notes and barnyard. Taste is more of the sour funky notes some oak barrel notes. I was expecting more but it was fine.

Thanks Brennan for sharing the bottle! Poured into a snifter showing moderately filtered orange with clean white foam lacing. 

The nose shows tart notes of apricot and light peach with light acetic notes. 

The palate is medium bodied and moderately carbonated. Very lightly tart with flavors of white wine with a white wine bitterness.

Bottle at Ratebeer Best Beer Festival. 31/01/2016. A clear golden amber coloured pour with a fine loose white head. Aroma is smoked lemon, juicy hop, lemon rind. Little tangy on the nose. Flavour is composed of tangy lemon rind, orange, little dank, apricot, preach. Lovely yeast character. Palate is refreshing and tart with highish carbonation.

From bottle at Ratebeer Best festival, Santa Rosa. Unclear orange color with off white head. Malty and yeasty aroma, funky, barnyard notes, citrusy fruity, floral and grassy, wood, vinous. Sweet, acidic and bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Sample from [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: pours pale golden haze with tiny unstable foamy off-white head. Aroma-flavors: intense hop profile with notes of tropical fruits like papaye, mango, pineapple, some citruses etc., hint of hrape in the background, slightly tart mouthfeel, dry finish. Body is moderate, texture soft, carbonation is medium.

Bouteille 37.5cl via trade, bottled 2015-10-10.
De couleur orange léger, col blanc léger et crémeux.
Arôme au nez fin de barrique laissant de fines effluves de brett et un rappel de vin blanc type Sauternes et Sauvignon. Houblonné vert perce en rétro-nasal avec un accord herbacé.
Palais est léger sur un profil offrant des notes de funk couplés à la barrique, ici une impression de vin blanc. Fini est finemetn poudreux, grains, et subtilement poivré.
Note verte houblonné, avec un retrait herbacé, impression de groseille à maquereau, raisin blanc. Le tout laisse un fini tirant sur le houblonnage à cru qui percute bien avec laspect funk, barrique de vin blanc et un fini sur une légère sécheresse de chêne.

Light brown with a small head. Almost exactly like the first batch of Nelson Sauvignon from Mikkeller. There is brett in the nose, dry oak, hints of sauvignon blanc, got that melon wine notes. Taste has slight sour wine notes, loads of Nelson, finish is more bitter than expected, hop character is obvious, more sauvignon blanc notes, almost velvet like. Excellent

As with most HF beers Ive had, nothing that hits you over the head, just wins you over with its expert execution. This yellow sour is equal parts citrusy hops and oaky barnyard funk. Light grass, goes down easy but leaves a lasting impression. Betwween 4.3-4.4 on this one.
375ml bottle shared. Clear copper pour. Aroma is citrus funk amazing. Taste follows, citrus, slightly bitter. So much going on, so glad to try this, crazy beer.
Bottle shared by Tom - thanks bro! Rich tropical fruit nose - intense citrus. Taste is right there with the aroma. Motherfucker - this is incredible.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. HFD #3 Bardzo owocowe, z delikatną kwasowością. Fajne.
Sample at RateBeer Best 2017. Comes a hazy, pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, tropical, and floral. Taste is pineapple, tropical, floral, and yeast. Delicious.
Bottle at RBBest. Pours pale yellow. Aroma is simple yeast, lots of white wine barrel. Body is medium with a light sourness for a great drinkability. Fruity and flowery palate. Delicious.
Taster at Ratebeer best. Pours a golden color with a bit of head. Mild sourness. Hops overpower a little.

January 26, 2017. Bottle at home, bottled October 10, 2015. 
Light hazy dark orange with a small dense off-white head. Aroma is lots of tropical fruit and brett, sweet overripe peaches, mango, pineapple, grape skins, lemon, some hoppy pine notes and soft oak. Taste is smooth tart, some sweet fruity notes. Medium bodied, soft to average carbonation, crisp yet creamy. Finish is tart with notes of passionfruit, citrus, some oak notes, sweet mango and pineapple, light dry oak and grape skins with some white wine notes. 
Great one, a smooth, slight tart very fruity and well balanced funky one.

375 ml. Bottle, hazy golden orange in color. Nose is tart tangerine peel, funky Brett, light wood, mild Lactic, mild subtle. 
Funky yeast, micro flora, some light dank citrus with plenty of complexity. Medium body and fine carbonation. Ton of shit going on here. And really drinkable for a guy who doesnt really like most sour ... Anything.

Poured from bottle thanks Heather_B copper orange with a thin white head. Aromas of grape skin wine citrus lemon zest. Taste is amazing well balanced notes of oak wine grapes and citrus. As usual an amazing mouthfeel.

375ml bottle shared by HeatherB. Thanks! Been wanting to try this for years! Pours orange brown with a few tiny off white bubbles. Aroma is white grape, HFS funk. Flavor is mildly tart white grape, orange, apricot, HFS funk. Slight astringency dries in the finish. Great stuff!

375ml bottle purchased on site. Pours copper orange, slightly hazy, frothy, fizzy, micro bubbles leaving lasting lacing. When stirred you get a nice fog throughout the beer. Smells winey, fruity, lemon citrus zest. Very sweet smelling. Best smelling HF saison Ive had to date. Tastes winey, sweet, sour, very orangey and some lemon zest as well. Very, very good. Smooth full mouthfeel, tart and sour aftertaste. Amazing. Love it.

From notes. Enjoyed at a tasting at Joshs house in Windsor on 12/19. 375 mL bottle, 2016 vintage. The pour is a darker golden orange with a thin ring of off white head that vanishes quickly without a trace. The aroma is really good here. Its like a juicy wine with a great light dry hoppiness on the back end. There is a nice tropical fruit, a hint of lemon, and a beautiful resinous pine. The flavor is just as good, if not better. The funk rises a little, and its fantastic. There is the fruits, the light white wine, a light barrel, a hint of dry hops, just everything you want. The mouth feel is great. Its crisp and clean with a beautiful carbonation and a lingeringly fruity and juicy finish with a light dry hop. Damn.

Bottle received in trade. Hazy deep yellow pour with a frothy white head. Insane tropical fruit and funk nose. Mango, star fruit, passion fruit. Fresh wood, white gapes & light diesel fuel. Sour fruity taste. Oily dry tart mouth. Lovely dry-hopped sour.
Bottle. Pours a bit cloudy amber with a nice head. Aroma is citrucy fruity mango hoppy pink a bit sweet caramel. Flavor is fresh citric hoppy fruity funky dry and a bit astringent.

Bottle. Hazy deep orange beer with a small head. Sourish hop aroma, tropical, mango, pine apples, vinous notes, cedar notes. Fruity tropical flavor, sourish, vinous notes, grapes, mango, tart, some cedar. Refreshing, really nice.
A: Hazy brown coloured with a thin white lacing N: Lime zest, pineapple, brett, passionfruit, mango T: Mango bomb! Pineapple, passionfruit O: Very heavy tropical fruits! Nice!

Batch 2, bottled 10/10/15, drunk 11/5/16.Lime-brass-tinted golden with good clarity and a medium-sized, white head that fizzles to a ring rather quickly.Juicy, indeed, in the nose, though having sat in the bottle for over a year, the juiciness is now provided by the brett and lactic acids. There is still some remnant of juicy hop notes, I believe, and the sum total aroma is very full of lime, nectarine, kumquat, gooseberry and yogurt cultures. Quite sniffable with light honey and biscuit malt character behind it. No alcohol. Maybe a touch over-acidic.In the mouth its both malty and very lactic. So it balances pretty nicely, but with a high amount of acidity lingering. Woody, lactic and with some hop bitterness lingering, as well. Very low carbonation but mostly tight/engaging. Quite nice, enjoyable stuff, though the lactic acid gets pretty strong over the course of the beer, unbalancing things slightly. A little bit monotonous but very good, nonetheless.

Bottle shared by a friend. Batch 2, poured a kind of copper colour with a non lasting white head. While pouring the room is filled with juicy white wine aromas, such a bright delicate dry white wine nose, clear influence of the new zeeland hops, Which adds even more white grape notes, light citrus, and sweet orange. Theres a light crisp sweeter malt notice, oak, tart funky yeast, barnyard funk and a Nice dry aftertaste. The name is just what you would expect from this brew, incredible juicy. Delicious brew.
Bottle at Warpigs. Hazy orange colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of citrus, lemon, oranges, tartness, acidic and brettanomyces.

Bottle @ the Dangerous Bottleshares Reunion/season premiere. Pours light hazy copper/bronze with a small head. White grapes, grape skin, light hops, citrus, oily mouthfeel, tons of oaky vanilla and some funk. Very good!

Bottle. Pours hazy orange/amber with a tiny white head. Aroma has a lot of nice funk, barnyard, green grapes, white wine, citrus, oaky vanilla and a nice basement. Complex and awesome! The taste is funky with oily white wine notes, barnyard, citrus, fruity hops, vinegar, oak and rural in a pleasant way! Juicy indeed and complex as well!

Bottle at the Dangerous Bottleshares Reunion/season premiere. Pours a hazy orange amber with a small white head. Aroma has stone fruits, hops, fruity tartness, smooth vanilla, some plums, mint, grapes or apples, oak, lots of funk. Taste is medium sour, subtle smooth vanilla sweetness, some funkish dryness. Fruity nelson-like hoppy, but without the bitterness. Super smooth body and an average carbonation.

Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares Reunion tasting / Reset #1. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aromas has funk, oak, brett, green grapes, white wine, stone fruits, citrus. Taste is vinous, oaky, stone fruits, citrus, brett, orange, vanilla, light sour.

You need some juice for ya breakfast? - why not the juiciest? 
Pour hazy amber, with a small white head. 
Aroma has plenty of citrus juicy goodness, with a whole lot of stonefruit and grape to back it up. Slight vanilla, grass and wood In here as well, making this very well put togethered, and very well balanced. Slight grassy and Green notes In here as well. 
Taste is somewhat sour, with a refreshing bitter feel to it. 
Medium bodied, with a flat but still sparkling (makes sense) carb. 
This is quit nice, with the wine barrel being rather present, giving this some nice white wine qualities.

Pours hazy to murky deep orange with a few bubbles settling along the edge of the glass. The nose is sour but distinctly HF. Which is just great. More gueuze than saison and more mineral than fruity but mostly sauvignon blanc white wine. Tastes refreshing and medium sour with enough undertones to keep it complex and multidimensional. Mineral fruits, sour barnyard hints but mostly just balanced. Finished pretty dry and with a long aftertaste. Really really good. Thanks to Alan for this beauty.

Batch 2. Merci à moi de mavoir partagé cette bouteille que je me suis domé comme un champion par ce bel après-midi de célébrations chez les Hexagonais. Du fond de mon ballon Hill Farmstead rempli de ce légendaire liquide à la robe bien ambrée et cristalline, jaillit une quantité impressionnante de fines bulles, à la manière dun vin mousseux. Les célébrations nationales se poursuivent jusque dans mon verre dirait-on. Cette myriade de fines bulles ne suffit pas à alimenter cette mousse, dabord jolie, qui en un clin doeil sest évanouie en ne laissant sur mon verre que de timides vestiges de son passage. En approchant mon grand nez fouineur de ma généreuse coupe, je ne tarde pas à en respirer de puissantes arômes de vin blanc, dune culture microbienne diversifiée, de fruit orange et de raisin vert, le tout bien composté dans une barrique autoritaire et suintante du vin qui rougit en ce moment même les joues de nos cousins français occupés à faire la fête. Les malts, trop souvent laissés pour contre lorsquil est question de bières sauvages, jouent à mon avis un rôle clé dans cette bière en apportant un contre-poids indispensable à cette pompeuse barrique très sûre delle-même. Un filme dhuile me tapisse les joues alors le bois fait tempête. Acidité modérée et bien balancée par les malts (que je salue à nouveau bien bas). Je sens cette puissante bière me colorer les joues. Tiens, je mangerais bien un cassoulet...
Magnum at Warpigs - Pours transparent amber. Nose is sour, tart, lemons, wine. Taste is slightly tart, acid, lemons, wine, oranges.

Sample from 1500 ml bottle at Warpigs, thanks a lot! Hazy orange with whiteish head. Aroma has orange, hoppy lemonade notes, citrus, lemon, lime, wheat, barrel notes and brett. Taste is similar, very juicy indeed, orange, passion fruit, mango, lemon and bretty barrel notes. Really nice
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2016 Amber pour. Big off white head. Little lacing. Huge orange juice aroma. Huge juice taste
Rating #6000. Bottle(batch 2). Hazy brown pour with tan head. Floral, fruity hop aromas, light wine, oak and tart tones. Lime, citrus, floral, wine and funky Flavors.

Sample from 1.5L Magnum (with mahoosive thanks to the ever generous Malmö Crew)@Hill Farmstead Day, Warpigs, Copenhagen (12/05/2016) - pours murky orange with a thin white head. Aroma and taste is massively fruity with big hitting peachy, orange, lemon notes, wood, sour and funky, tart fruity finish.

Clear copper-gold color, frothy off-white head. Apples, grapes, citrus, and lemons on the nose. Light funkiness and very mild tartness reminiscent of a white wine. Lively, crisp, and light bodied. Moderately dry finish.
Rusty pour. Nose is minty, musty, stale hops. Taste is citrus, wine barrel, aged hops, tart juicy finish.

Bottle sampled @ Hopishop #3. 2015 10 10. Wowza this one was expensive. Dark orange with no head. Nose is massive white wine funk, raw funk, massive white wine, indeed hugely juicy with some kiwi, citrus, as with the other HF brett, beers, brett, bacteria etc. are massive & almost chewy here, same goes for the taste. Taste is indeed massively juicy rustic white wine, wet burlap sack, wild grape, massive brett, white grape, funk, wine is massive & delicious on this one, low lemon, juicy green apple. Thick chewy brett body & massive wine. This one already carries quite a bit of age but I do feel like it would improve even further & clean out a bit. Still this is indeed massively juicy & with vibrant & rich wine tastes. I touch less dominant HF brett would improve this one a bit for me but already very nice & aptly named.

Bottle from thepatrickman-thanks for a huge longtime want! Pours a deep bright orange. Nose is bright orange citrus and some dank, slightly catty hops, along with some wine barrel, and sweaty and tropical brett character. Mouthfeel is plush with solid malt back with flavors following the nose. Slightly chewy and drying finish.

bottle shared with and courtesy of Kermis.
No head. Hazy light amber pour. Tart aftertaste
On tap at RateBeer Best 2016. Pour is hazy golden with a medium white head. Notes of grapefruit, light citrus, zest, sour grapes, and a bit of sulfur. Finish has more brett and sour mash.
Smells like a general sour. Taste is super nice and smooth lactic and citric sour. Medium body, low carbonation, and no foam.

Poured from bottle into a tulip: Pours hazy golden with a foamy white head. Aroma of citrus zest, straw, brat funk, little tart, and oak. Taste is mild chardonnay, citrus, funk, lightly tart, and finishes with apple. Soft mouthfeel, tons of flavor, this is an incredible beer and I want more.

Batch 2. This is one of Hill Farmsteads finest. Every ingredient is expertly made and the balance and combination is just about flawless. It starts with a complex aroma of hops, brett funk, and malt that blew me away, and then it followed up with barnyard leather, hop bite, and a bit of sweetness. Unbelievably smooth mouthfeel with a fantastic, creamy carbonation. One for the record books.

12.7 oz bottle, B2. Misty orange brown with a clingy head. Nose is grass, lime, toffee, green apple and yeast. Juicy medium body with fuzzy carb and a lingering sour buzz. Taste is chardonnay, kiwi, grass and lime sherbet. Beautifully nuanced with muted sour and subtle sweetness.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2016 I never got to try the old bottling so I wanted to try the new one while it was fresh. Thanks *****(REDACTED)***** for getting it. The nose is like an 11 for me because it combines my life of juicy (heh) fresh NZ hops with that beautiful HF yeast funk and tartness. It?s a surprisingly less complex beer on the palate, and I?m ultimately not sure that it?s all that much better than the best bottles of Rayon Vert. That?s not a slight, since I still own bottles of practically ancient Rayon Vert, but it?s definitely a relation that makes one choke up a bit at this beer?s secondary market price tag.Oh who the hell am I kidding, YOLO and this beer is delicious.

1st of 4 bottles. Seems like a good Valentines Day beer. Clear amber pour - really pretty - with no head. Smells like a cross between a tart saison and a very hoppy pale ale. Unique. Mouthfeel is good but I always like a bit more carbonation than this offers. Taste starts with juicy (no pun) hops and ends with a tart apple finish. Wine barrel comes through the whole time with that rich undertone. Im digging it. Happy to have more to enjoy over the next year.

Bottle thanks to my_knew_craft, thanks a lot Joey! Pours a clear copper with a medium offwhite head that quickly recedes into a thein veil that leaves good lacing. Nose is of dilly oak, red wine, grapefruit. Taste is lightly tart and incredibly vinous. Some distinctive lime flavors. Red wine. Moderately bitter. Body is medium, carbonation moderately low and mouthfeel certainly juicy and gouleyant. Incredibly refreshing and classy. Another Hill Farmstead world class brew!
[1/31/16] Bottle sample at RateBeer Best festival in Santa Rosa. Golden. "Green" hops, funk, wood, tart, fruity. Medium-bodied.

Bottle at RB Best Festival, 31/01/16.
Clear golden with a decent off white cap. 
Nose is tarte citric peel, funky, light wood must, tangerine, melon, pissy lemon. 
Taste comprises tangy orange, lemon tinged straw, light yeast, brett strokes, barnyard, on the turn satsuma, light wood rebuff, damp hay, barnyard. 
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a light puckering edge.
Solid sour ... great balance.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle - Lots of fruit and grapefruit. Clear gold. Tart acidic citrus and a dry finish. Nice but a bit overhyped in my mind.

Bottle at RateBeer Best. It pours a clear deep orange color with a white head. The aroma is funky and herbal with some over ripe apricots. The flavor is the same. Herbal, funky apricot and grapefruit. A little hard candy-like fruitiness. Some minerals on the palate. Surprisingly full bodied for the style, but dry and tart in the finish. Higher notes of alcohol are noticed. Overall, very good.
Bottle. Amber beer with a cream head. Tart and citrusy aroma. Tart/light sour flavor with citrus and light tropical fruit. Medium bodied. Tartness lingers with citrus and light summer fruit.
Pour from bottle at rate beer festival 2016. Pours orange with a tart aroma. Taste is tart with a fruity finish. Great beer.

Bottle, poured by JesusOfVT. Clear orange liquid with medium white head. Aroma of lemon, fresh hops, apples, light grain, light wood and barnyard. Taste is very light sweet and light to medium sour with notes of lemons, wood and mango. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Great.

Bottle at RBWG 2016. Nose is a soft lemon and hay. Very clear orange with small white head. Some apricot as it warms. Taste isnt that tart. Moderate orange character. Decent but more like a saison. Not very funky
From bottle at Ratebeer Awards. Pours orange copper with a tiny beige head and a fruity sroma. There is a sourish very unusual fruit and light malt flavor. Delicate and delicious.

(375ml bottle) slightly cloudy deep gold, lasting fine white bubbles and nice lacing. Nose of slightly earthy brett, typical Hill Farmstead funk/terroir, saison yeast, wine barrel, very slight hint of manure/dairy cows, touch of souring bacteria, clean and bright, dry hops, citrus peel and pulp, touch of minerality and chalkiness too. Exceptionally complex. Taste is even better, touch of brett, horseblanket, citrus peel, wine barrel (white wine?), souring bacteria (though mildly so), medium carbonation, excellent palate finish.

Poured a lightly hazy straw yellow with a white head. Aroma was of citrus rind, light funk, grassy hops, brett. Flavor similar, moderately tart, lots of sweet tart character. Pretty damn good, but not quite the magic of some of their others.

Batch 2 shared by Matt. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a fluffy white head. Aromas of orange and lemon zest. Light mineral quality. More sour than expected. Taste was medium strong sour. Finished fairly clean. Medium thick body and medium low carbonation.

Batch 2 bottle. Pours a hazy golden color, orange hues....almost peach in color. Small fizzy white head breaks into some fine lace. Aromas have a noticeable Brett character, vinous notes with oak, some mineral notes and some stonefruit. Taste is initially dry Brett and oak upfront, but hits a nice light tart note mid-palate. Grapefruit juice is what I get here. Transitioning into some peach, mango, nectarine sweetness. Finishes with nice wine barrel touches, dry and clean. Light mineral notes. Really tasty stuff and glad to have tried it!

Clear copper body with a thin off-white cap. Aromas of wine, honey, brett, mineral water. Funky. Huge brett character. Light in body with little carbonation. Biscuit / cracker notes. Earthy. Rain water and citrus. Delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2016 Pours a dark orange with some brown hues. The aroma has tons of citrus, oak, vinegar with a hint of alcohol. The flavor is more sour and the palate is juicy. This is a serious beer.

Batch 2. Bière embouteillée le 10 octobre 2015. Merci à Stoned99. Une robe un peu rousse avec une mousse qui fond vite. Aucune dentelle nest visible sur la paroi de mon verre Hill Farmstead. Au nez, des activités caramélisées se manifestent à travers de solides effluves de barriques qui transpirent le vin et lacide acétique. Au goût, voilà un retour du boisé avec cette trace de coco et cette acidité légèrement fruitée qui demeure correctement plaisante. En bouche, je regarde un corps qui porte les stigmates du style. Au final, voici la force de la barrique utilisée, malhabile certainement puisque trop puissante mais rigolote dans sa façon de se présenter à mon cerveau, ce fin analyste parfois creux et trop souvent rempli de saloperies.

375ml bottle drank on the premise. Aroma: loads of white wine, herbal, fruity and a tad funky. App: cloudy orange, small white white with yellow tint in it and as always great lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, fruity, medium sweetness combined with acidity and bitter finish. Overall: for sure this is something unique. Somehow something bothered me in the aroma. Too herbacy? Weird that I thought it was herbacy, but there was something I didnt appreciate that much. Not too sure. Anyway, this certainly is a great HF.

Bottle that I took to Max & Jesss for an impromptu barbecue thing when I was down for Comic Con.. Pours a hazed amber with a thin white head. Musk and a bit of citrus with a touch of sweet tropical fruit. Medium bodied, sweet funk and citrus, a touch of fruit. Tart and tangy with a bit of citrus, musk and wood. Funk and tangy. Gorgeous.

375 mL bottle. Unknown originally review date, but I had this fresh.
 Hazy orange. A little hazy and murky looking. Nice white head. Gushed a little.
Citrusy aroma. White wine. Bright and acidic. Hoppy orange with some lemony aromas.

Taste very bright orange citrus. Acidic white wine. Grainy malts. White wine lingers past the citrus flavors, but the hops come through to provide some bitterness in the back.

Crisp. Dare I say refreshing. Well carbonated.

Extremely impressive. This review is from the first time I had this beer, which was pretty fresh. I was surprised to find this review after years. It does lose its punch and unique hop flavors after a while, but it remains a good beer.

Bottle at Max and Jesss housewarming. Courtesy of Jay - thanks for this treat. Pours a hazy murky orange with white lacing. Mouthfeel is tart and juicy, medium-bodied; notes of dank fruits, tart sour candy and light minerality on the palate.

375 ml bottle shared by urbancaver- thanks again, Cam! Pours a cloudy orange gold with a small wispy white head that leaves a ring around the edge, too. The aroma was malty and musty, and I couldnt get a whole lot through it; notes of orange zest, bread, mineral water, grass, and hay. The flavor brings more "Juicy" character, with orange, pineapple, bready malts, earth, hay, peach, apricot - nice and funky. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a funky, fruity mouthfeel. Mineralic, too. Doesnt live up to the hype, or maybe its just aged out of its prime; drink or trade if you still have one. Do not age any longer.

Small bottle at home. Pours hazy dark golden orange with a small white head. Nice tangerine and orange peel aroma, some dried peach, thyme and white wine notes. Light to medium body with a nice subtle sourness going over in a dry soft bitterness.
Taste is lots of stewed peach, aftertaste is soo nice, like a fine orange bitter.

Bottle 375ml. [ As Hill Farmstead Juicy ].Unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy - creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel - pale malt, grass, peel - zest, leather, funky, tart, fruity, wood, oxidide notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet, moderate acidic and bitter with a long duration, tart, yeasty, orange - citrus, peel - zest bitter, leather - funky, light oxidide. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20141227]

Bottle @ New Years Tasting, courtesy of kermis. Pours a hazy orange beer with a small white head on top. Aroma of barnyard, horse manure, dusty blankets. Flavor is medium sour, slightly yeasty breadyness in there, fruity and has some vineous characters in the back. Great complexity going on here, even after the age.

Bottle shared at The Hague New Year Whale Session. Pours very hazy amber with an off white head. Aroma is super funky, major barnyard and manure, grapefruit, citrus, orange. Still pretty fruity but the funk is awesome. Flavour is light sweet and moderate acidic. Medium to light full bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Hazy orange with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, grapefruit, wood and bretty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 271214

Pours hazy golden with a fading offwhite head. Aroma of light sourness, malt, yeast, brett, wood, light sweetness, light vanilla, wine barrels. Flavor is light sourness, light malt, oak, bretty, fruit, wine barrel, grapes. Medium body, average carbonation, light bitter finish. 271214

Bottle. Hazy amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, baking yeast, fruit, oak, little sour and spicy. Flavour is malt, baking yeast, little sour, oak, wood, little sour, medium dry, little lemon, little leather and medium bitter.
Bottle @ Højbjerg juletasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, brett, yeast, citrus, white wine, malt and hops.
Bottle. Creamy White good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter sour finish. oily palate.

Bottle, thanks so much Mike for busting out the heavy hitters last night. Glad to finally revisit this after nearly 2 years. Aroma is mega grapefruit rind, overripe tropical fruit, lots of lime, pink grapefruit pith, subtle oak, RUSTIC, dusty earthy brett. There is noticeable funk, but grapefruit and lime are the dominate aromas. The beer pours cloudy amber/orange with fizzy off white head that sizzles out pretty quickly. Taste is dominated by grapefruit rind with moderate bitter quality towards the end. Lime is present as well, with fruity brett, overripe fruit funk, tangerines, oak tannins. The body is light, with medium-high carbonation, dry bitter finish, medium astringency. Aftertaste is pepper, grapefruit, melon and faint wine. Overall, the brett, fruit and oak work very well together with extreme depth, but I am surprised to see this beer have bitterness to it after almost 2 years. The bitterness seems a bit overpowering to the delicate nature of most Hill Farmstead farmhouse beers, but still stupid good.

Bottle with huge thanks to Reynolds314! Shared with friends. Pours clear amber, cloudier toward the sediment. Medium off-white head that sticks around and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is Brett, very citrusy - tangerine and lime. Light tart, light funk, light bitter, lots of citrus, grapefruit, tropical limes (if there is such a thing), a bit of dustiness and pepper as well. Medium body, medium carbonation. Hella good.

In short: A complex and highly drinkable amber ale with superb farmhouse-funk character. Excellent wild ale.
How: Bottle 375ml, twice, one bottle fresh and one bottle 10 months old, different beer, I preferred the dryer aged bottle that Im rating here.
The look: Cloudy glowing amber body topped by a small white head.
In long: WARNING: My aged bottle was a moderate gusher. Nose is moderately wild with a farmhouse bretty character that is very much barnyard. Aroma also has tropical fruits and some fun aged cheddar undertones. In mouth the beer has a medium+ body size, a texture that is somewhat chewy-doughy, a lively carbonation with very soft bubbles, an overall very comfortable mouthfeel. The aged bottle was less fruity and juicy (pardon the pun) than the fresh one but I loved its dryness and the stronger farmhouse character. This one doesnt seem to be developing the signature tartness of many other HF wild beers, this is a pure wild ale, not your usual Sour/Wild Ale by ratebeer standards, nothing sour here, this beer is actually quite sessionnable. I drank my last bottle of Juicy and now my heart is broken I repeated for a third time to the man who kept saying sir, this is 911, whats your emergency?.

Bottle thanks to Gibson. Pours a cloudy orange with small off white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is strong yeast, apricot, brett, papaya juice. Thin mouthfeel with nice crisp fruit, funk, brett with light dry finish. Easy to drink, very impressive.

Bottle at home, shared with and thx to Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: fruity, hoppy, older hops, rather sweet, some lemon.
TASTE: fruity, very fresh, hoppy, sour, some wood. Very nice!

Tasted under less than ideal circumstances B.C."H.", fully hazy orange-brown beer. Acidic nose, with even a touch of acetic - if fleetingly. Pear juice, maltsyrup, cookies or waffles in syrup; then fruit, maybe strawberry or blue grape. Sweetish with a faint sourish edge. Mainly fruity flavours, but very difficult to imply any specific fruit. Vinous - the wine barrels coming through. Flat, but that might be attributable to the circumstance. Slightly (fruit?)slick. Pharmaceutical/mannah in the aftertaste. Very nice - big thanks to Mathieu!

375ml bottle.  Big thanks to Dany for hooking up this impossible to land beer.  Sampled against a stellar lineup of sours.  Peppery. Slightly lemony. Saison-ish. Not impressed after the rest of the lineup.

38cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, with Brettanomyces, thx alot to my German friends for sharing!, very complex sour brew, fruity/woody and slightly vinous/bitter, very balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew

Pour is copper orange with a thin tan head that dissipates immediately. Nose is fruity, light hints of brett and some peppery yeasty notes with some malt lingering in. Lots of mango and tropical fruit. Taste is sweet and fairly bright. Brett is underneath but a hint disorganized. Lots of mango and pineapple. Tropical fruits with the Brett and notes of muddled malt trough the finish. Body is light with very strong carbonation as semi dry finish.
Bottle with adnielsen. Pours a slightly hazy orange. Tart citrus, dry, really nice funk. Very solid beer.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle, hazy orange pour with white head, aroma brought notes of melon, lemon, grass, vanilla, nice biscuit, bready notes, very nice smelling, Taste is a mix of lemon, melon, hints of white fruit into some peach, slight earth, spice, finishing fairly dry, slightly sweet. Delicious.

Bottle @ Armins house, courtesy of lukaduke. Thanks! Pours a murky orange appearance with an off white head. Spicy herbal, a touch dank, melon, tropical fruity, bright fruity aroma. Fairly sour, melon, cantaloupe, pineapple, juicy pretty, lemon, oaky flavor that finishes pretty dry and tropical. Good.

Bottle shared by LeninCat @ Armins - thanks! Big hoppy and tropical fruit and funk in the nose. Hazy yellow pour with a nice white head. Taste is really nice - refreshing, bright, hoppy and just a bit of tartness and bitterness in the finish.
Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen shithead for sharing. Pours a golden color with white head. Melon, tart, hoppy, citrus flavors. Nice fruity tart beer.
Bottle. Medium orange pour, quickly dissipating carbonation with an aroma of bitter orange. Flavor is slightly muted bitter oranges and nicely bitter on the aftertaste.

A- pours a hazy golden yellow with a delicate white head that dissipates quickly. Virtually no lacing. S- fantastic pineapple, grapefruit, grass, sweet cream butter, oak, musty/dank New England farmhouse, wool, lemon, white wine grapes, herbal spices, coriander, astringent, and manzanita blossoms. M- light sticky body with a dry, sweet and sour medium palate. Bright carbonation. T- pineapple and grapefruit are strong, wild and pleasant up front. Malts, melon and brett throughout. Oak, must, herbal spices, white wine in the dry middle. Stone fruit supports. Long bitter ending is lemon zest, grapefruit, white pepper, zinc, cheese funk. Great beer for Thanksgiving dinner.

Bottle. Oteyj you are the man. Stunning opaque peach colored pour with a giant fluffy white head. Nose and flavor are outrageous; legitimately ridiculous. Apricot, mango, blood orange, lemon, cheesecloth, horseblanket.... the list goes on. An awesome combination of fruit and funk. Hill Farmstead saison/barrel program at its finest.

bottle thanks to my brah tom10101. pours hazy and glowing golden orange with a very nice white head, good retention and lacing. juicy fruits - no, not the gum, tropical guava, loads of mangoes and melons, peppery and dusty bretts, very nice lightly acidic profile, bit of cheese and sweetness, bitter herbs and a bit of grass. bright carbonation, light to medium body - oily and juicy - did i just use that term again? yes because this beer is all about juiciness, finishes herbal-floral-citrusy and relatively dry bretty and astringent. perfect mouthfeel. truly enjoyed this gem! hf at its best! its like having little mimosa, for those who have had the opportunity and privilege to taste both!

A: Hazy Orange Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Chardonnay, Tropical Fruit, Oranges, Pineapple

T: Yeast, Grapefruit, Orange Rind, Papaya, Mild Chardonnay

M: Decent Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, Lightly Sweet, Lightly Bitter

Overall, a truly solid beer with bright fruit flavors from the hops.

500th rating in 6 years (I am so lazy). Should be rating 5000. Poured into my Hill Farmstead tasting glass. Pours a hazy golden orange with a nice pure white head. A combination of the micro flora and hops lend this beer and amazing dank citrus aroma with plenty of barnyard funk. I really wonderful use of bacteria and hops. great beer!

Bottle opened 6/22/13, poured into a HF taster glass.

A-Upon opening, this one is a bit of a gusher. Nothing bad, but if I hadnt started pouring the beer would have gone all over the table. It pours dark copper verging on red with effervescent carbonation running throughout the beer. It is very cloudy from some yeast sediment that got kicked up from the gushing bottle. A two inch fluffy white head falls a little over the first minute, but remains on top of the beer throughout the entire glass. Some yeast sediment settles at the bottom of the glass.

S- Lactic acidity as well as brett is apparent on the nose. Grapefruit and citrus is also there, although I cant tell if it is from the hops or bugs. There is a very interesting barnyard/musty note as well, most likely from the brett. 

T- Up front is some phenolic brett, although right away the flavor is dominated by a grapefruit juice like flavor that immediately dries everything out. There is a tiny bitter note on the end, although with the complexities in this beer, it is easy to miss. 

M- It starts out extremely effervescent, with high carbonation, but not over the top. There is medium body that sits right where I want it for a beer like this- not too over the top, but still apparent enough. After you swallow, your mouth is immediately dried out, and without another sip will remain that way for quite a while! This beer encourages you to keep drinking it. 

O- Incredibly complex beer from start to finish. I was expecting more hop flavors, but It seemed like the bugs have really taken over on the flavor front of things, making for a very interesting wild ale. The only real fault I see with this beer is that I dont have another to age out and see how it develops over time.

Notes from Saturdays tasting.
Aroma is fairly hop forward with lots of citrus and lighter notes of tropical fruit, melon and white grapes. Faint phenolics and light oak character.
Pours a cloudy orange with a thin white head that shows average retention and light lacing.
Flavor is fairly juicy with moderately high tropical fruit and citrus juice. Lighter notes of melon and white wine. Moderately high bitterness. Faint phenolic yeast character.
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Noticeable light hop astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. The hop astringency could be attributed to the fact that this was the first hoppy beer of the evening and a bit of a shock to the palate.
Overall a fairly enjoyable beer, but also one of my lesser enjoyed beers of the evening. While I thought the flavors all worked together and the beer was indeed juicy, I feel like we have moved away from the delicateness that I find so enjoyable about the Hill Farmstead beers. Its almost like the hops hid all my favorite parts of Seans beers.

Bottle shared at Collected Works tasting. Cheesey lactic notes in the nose, passionfruit and lemon, sour fruit melding well with the classic blast of tropicalia thanks to Nelson. Grapefruit soda flavor, lemongrass and lemon verbena, killer bitterness. A quite ambitious beer executed perfectly.

Damn good saison here. Amost a year old, hops have faded a bit but still getting the citus and bitterness. Sour, tropical fruit, lots of brett, oak, white wine, lemon, white grape and some spice. Very complex. I notice something different with each sip. Deadly stuff. I can only wish i tried this fresher. Shared with my wife to celebrate the babys 8 months.
Bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head. Has a fruity peachy hoppy bretty aroma. Fruity sour tart peachy hoppy flavor. Has a fruity sour tart bretty peachy hoppy bitter finish.

Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Cloudy golden - white head. Lovely fruity and bretty aroma, citrus, acid notes, nice hoppy, wooden notes, dryness, light malty, tropical fruits, light notes of grapes, lovely bretty taste. Fantastic balance and high drinkability.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour with a slice of white foam. Aroma is quite hoppy, I was a little (pleasantly) surprised considering it has been released a while ago. Very fruity, tropical and citrusy, fruity white wine notes with a hint of that brett and oak. Taste is fruity but with much more brett character, tart but not sour, passion fruit and sauvignon blanc. Palate is med bodied with light carbonation, but still quite refreshing. Yum.

Bottle.
Hazy golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, pine needles, citrus peel and brett with notes of basil.
Fruity flavour of hops, citrus peel and brett with acidic notes.
Tart finish.

Shared with timfoolery. I thought this would be extremely fruity from the name, but it was more subtle and very well balanced. Grapefruit, lemon zest, brett, and the New Zealand hops work well in this. Great beer!

37.5 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is bretty, grapefruity and peachy. Smooth fruity, tart and citric. Solid bretty and grapefruity. Bitter and lingering fruity finish. Smooth.

Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a yellowish head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, black pepper, peaches, oranges, and spicy hops. The flavor is acidic with notes of brettanomyces, alcohol, peaches, black pepper, and spicy hops, leading to a dry finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a creamy white head. The aroma is loaded with fruity notes along some brett. Passion fruit. The flavor is highly fruity and has some acidic notes. Juicy indeed!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

cloudy orange, small white head.
very nice yeasty and slightly wild yeasty spicy aroma, notes of citrus. flavor is wild yeasty, citrussy, fruity, dry sourish, saison, wood?, one of the very best saison beers i have had.

37,5cl. Trade with AdamJackson. Cheers. Pours slight unclear Golden with a frothy White head. Nose is Brett, Wood and fruit. Tart and dry fruity flavor with massive Brett , Wood , Wine,  orange and citrus lingering. Complex and balanced. Quite some hops as well. Perfection!
bottle at chopkofest pours medium amber, lots of citrus, lemon and orange peel. slightly tart and puckering. finishes slightly dry.

Bottle from HF trade. Aroma and flavor of citrus, mostly orange and grapefruit. Definitely fits the name, but I was expecting more fruity flavors. Despite this, an excellent, excellent beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml from Timfoolery, citrus flavor, sour aroma, slightly cloudy, blanket at the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours a hazy, pale amber with a smallish, off-white head. Thick, Bretty nose with quite some grapefruit zest thrown in. Medium body, an initial sweetness and then again loads of Brett, sulphur, sour grapes and again zesty citrus. Ends dry and more bitter than really astringent. Complex yet very drinkable. 030713
Bottle in trade. Pour is hazy copper with a large white head. Aroma and flavor with notes of faint funk, light hop, light fruity sweetness, and a touch of wood. Very refreshing and easy to drink.

17th April 2013Stouts III Tasting. Big thanks to my Hill Farmstead pusher - Leighton. Cloudy amber beer, little white head. Palate is light and a little crisp, semi dry. Strong floral start and then a little tangerine peel and subtle wine and wood. Finishes dry and a little bitter. A curious beer but tasty.

transparent gold, puffy white head. Dusty nose is bright, lightly acetic, peach. Salty, bright flavor is heavy citrus in tangerine, strong lactic presence. light aspirin through the end. Lightly under carbonated body, bit of lactic. Reminds of Deviation without the control.

12.7oz bottle in a Hill Farmstead tulip.  Pours cloudy, amber/orange with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of Brett, white wine, citrusy and floral hops, tropical fruits, and some light malts.  Flavor the same, with an insanely fruity, hoppy beer that has a great wine/Brett finish.  Smooth texture.  A crazy good beer that Im very glad to have tried.

375ml bottle thanks to GT2.  Pours a hazy orange with some thick, white head.  Nose is very nice, big citrus bit not like an IPA, zesty heading towards pithy, plenty of Hill Farmstead house yeast character, tangerine, quite delicate.  Flavor is also delicate, sweet orange juice, tangerine, a little lime, white grape, almost a German/Riesling grapey-ness, guava.  Medium bodied, dry, zesty finish.  Refreshing.

Bottle shared by Markwise, thanks Mark.  Poured a hazy orangish color with aromas of huge tropical fruits, mango and pineapple with some brett thrown in.  Flavors were the same, nice tropical fruits, light tartness and funkiness, another solid beer from these guys.

Bottle @ The Stouts Tasting Pt III - Brokeback Edition. Generously supplied by Leighton. The pours hazy gold with a medium white head. Somewhat of a gusher from the bottle. The nose is mango fruit smoothie. Smashed banana and melon. Orange fruit leather. The taste is orange jellies. Dank attic and sock. Wild yeastiness. Slightly chalky. Mild bretty bite in the finish. Medium body, full carbonation. Overall, decent but not special. This felt like a step down from all of the other HF beers that Ive tried.

Bottle thanks to Leighton, shared at Stout 3 & Freestyle tasting. It pours murky amber with a small white head. The nose is earth, soft fruit, nectarine, peach, underlying sweetness, grape, light mouldy wood, barnyard and potpourri. The taste is earth, hay, barnyard, mouldy wood, pepper, vinous, light sourness, floral, wood, cobwebs, alcohol warmth and light bitterness with a dry, lightly tart finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Interesting flavour profile for sure, I just dont thing it melds together that well.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2013 Bottle shared at the Stouts Pt. III & Others: The Brokeback Tasting - London. Thanks to Matt for trading this to me. Pours lightly fuzzy, bright orange with a fine, creamy, pure white head. Nice bit of funk in the nose, some dried oranges, hints of brett, some poo and barnyard. Light to medium sweet flavor, some dried citrus, poop, dry wood, definite tang, melon, grapefruit, orange. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Light warmth to finish, some bitter orange rind, musty barnyard, more dry wood, poop, pine needles, tangerine, melon. Delicious stuff overall.

375mL thanks to a generous BA. Pours clear, bright orange. Weaker, acid cut foam. Nose is actually very juicy, so much fresh guava, Goya guava paste, rich and plump papaya. Bright and forward nectar fruits with clearly distinguishable house yeast reminiscent of Civil Disobedience and their other saison series. Taste is zesty, still hoppy, fresh tangerine and guava paste. Palate is quenching, buoyant. So good, but this beer beckons for large gulps but since it is so rare, youll be sharing it probably. But then it comes in a 375mL bottle, and there just isnt enough to get that super refreshing gulp that it deserves.

Bottle courtesy of GT2, thank you sir!  Cloudy golden yellow color, thick whitebhead, solid lacing. Aroma of pineapple, mango, breadfruit, passionfruit. Taste isslightly tart tropical fruit, fresh coconut, su tle. Itter and resiny finish. Amazing.

Bottle shared by GT2.  Pours lightly hazy orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is dank, orange, straw and biscuit malt with pear esters, barnyard and funky yeast.  Flavor is medium hops and bitterness, fruity esters, barnyard and funky yeast with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle. Pours apricot gold with white head. Nose is intense tangerine, citrus rind, grapefruit zest, Brett, farmhouse funk, apricot pit, orange peel and mango. Tons of citrus. Taste is the same with a slightly dry sour finish. White wine notes. Medium body.

375ml bottle. Nice... Pours a hazy deeper golden copper penny consistency throughout and topped with a creamy fluffy white head that reduces down to a thin wispy film... Aroma of floral bitterness with pear fruit accents. Somewhat milky creamy feel to it. Hops still present but that floralness just runs rampant in the nicest way imaginable... Flavors are a continuation of the same with pear and white grapes with some floral aspects that add to its enjoyment. Medium fluffy mouthfeel with just the right level of carbonation. Drinks nicely all around. Splendid.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours dirty pink/salmon with low white head. Aroma is of grapefruits, fruits, funk. Taste is of grapefruits, fruits, funk. Palate: Ligth body. Overall: Interesting grapefruits. Very refreshing. Pretty good, but I expected even a bit more, reading some reviews.

Bottle (375 ml). Thanks to Matt for this one! Hazy orange with a medium white head and good lacing. Aroma of grapefruit, tropical fruits, slight sourness, winey  and cheesy notes and some hops. Taste is slightly to moderately tart/sour with grapefruit, tropical fruits, wine, lemon and slight bitterness. Mouthfeel is winey and dry. Good complexity and balance. Drinkable and pleasant to drink. Good Sour!

Hazy dark golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus, wood, wild yeast, tropical fruits. Taste of strong citrus, wood, light wine, toast, and wild finish.
Bottle shared at Hunahpus Day. Dang this thing is tart and sour. Screams of cherries and grapes. Damn delicious.

375 ml bottle to snifter (shared with brew3crew and the Mrs.; thanks xerenthar). Looks good; a murky orange with off-white lacing. Smells good; spicy, doughy, yeasty, oaky, and wild. Tastes like it smells, but hopper, with a nice, dry mouthfeel. Good beer.

From a bottle, pours a glowing peach with a soapy white head.  Wicked globs of brown yeast were stuck to the cap and bottle neck.  Nose is really wine forward, with lots of stone fruit, tropical fruit, grassy hops, lots of bugs and wild yeast.  Mouth is sharp upfront with a dryer feel than I expected.  Still lots of wine barrel and wild yeast throughout the palate, but a really nice dry champagne quality that I enjoy a lot.  Carbonation is sharp.  Lots of green apple and bright citrus expression emerge.  Grassy and yeasty to a degree, but light and dry.  I personally prefer less overt wine barrel in these kinds of beers, but this is darn good.  Probably not quite Ann level.  Actually drinks similarly to a really nice bottle of Orval, like 1-2 years old.

Pour from a 375 ml. bottle into a HF glass. Golden orange with some cloudiness to the beer. Aromas of mild funk,brett, and interesting wild flora. Medium in body and very soft and silky smooth on your palate.. Flavors are reminiscent of Mimosa with oranges, tropical fruit, oak and wine. Nice long finish. Fantastic beer and would love to get another.

Sampled at Rories house.  I got the bottom of the bottle and it was full of yeast.  Otherwise it is golden with a white head.  Thevaroma was funky sour and sweet.  This is big time funky.  It is spur but not overly so.  Malty and ligjt hops.  Interesting.

Murky gold/brown pour, foamy whitish head. Gushed a little. Aroma hits with heavy doses of guava, leather, roasted lemons, Parmesan cheese and a hint of stone fruit. Flavor is so juicy and tart with dancing edges of sweetness. Yeast, lemons, brett, earthy funk. A masterpiece.
From Dak.  Aroma has guava, NZ hops.  Taste is sweet, a little salty and tart.  Quite dry reminiscent of citrus pith.   Really good.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2016 Hazy golden-peach colored body, medium to large white head, spotty lacing. Bottle was a gusher. Bretty with a strong citric-rind profile. Straw, must, and some hop bitterness. Medium to light bodied, incredibly dry finish, light bitterness, mild acidity. Nice, I think I preferred Mimosa though.

Bottle thanks to Corbet! Pours a dark straw color.
Smell is super stinky funk--very horsey.
Cheesy nose and taste. Nice citrusy, grassy hop character.
Reminds me a bit of batch 2 E. Medium body. Medium to high carbonation. Dry and delicious.

Bottle generously shared by ctipping.  Clear yellow pour with a white head.  Hoppy aromas.  Mellow hop notes with tasty orange highlights.  Good body, good carbonation, and good balance.  A very tasty brew..

Huge, huge thanks to Evan for this one. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

Slow gusher as I pop the cap. Nothing big, but have a glass at the ready. Pour yields a deep peach-colored brew with a nice two-finger white head. Good retention and plenty of lacing as it goes down. Thin cap throughout.

The initial nose provides a good dose of honeydew alongside tropical fruit. Mild funk and white-wine character in the background. Touch of citrus rind and very light straw.

Flavor is incredible. Absolutely fantastic. Notes of melon and white wine overlay a very light acidity. Just a touch of oak in the background as well as some mild underlying Brett. 

Body is light with a mild underlying bitterness. Acidity is quite light and is more along the lines of a mild citrus character rather than straight lactic acid. Theres a touch of creaminess in the background. Perhaps not creamy, but just a bit of wheat character. 

Overall, on the level with the best Hill Farmstead beers. Phenomenal, to say the least. Can we officially name Hill Farmstead the best brewery in the world?

Bottle... Hazy golden ale with a fizzy, white, fleeting head. Apricots and peaches are featured in the fruity, lightly funky nose. Medium-bodied and lightly creamy with moderate carbonation. The flavor is excellently-balanced between fruity tartness, crusty bitterness and pale grain sweetness. Finishes bready, mildly bitter and quite fruity. Bottle courtesy of the ever-generous ctipping!

375 mL bottle, thanks Starr!

Pours a hazy and dull golden amber with a thin off white head. Acidic aroma of lemon and wine with some leafy tropical hops and grass. Medium thick body with soft carbonation and a long lasting orange pulp/resin and leafy hop finish. Bright flavor of orange peel, lemon, grass, white wine and bready malt. Notes of Mimosas citrus flavor are present but tempered in a welcomed way. Reminds me a lot of my favorite batches of Vautour, with the balance of grassy and lemon saison notes with the wine and orange of the barrel aging.

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy orange with a long-lasting, fluffy white head and great lacing. Big bretty, fruity, tropical aroma; pineapple, orange zest, papaya, grass, biscuit, mango, and honey. Taste is tart and fruity, brett, bread, somewhat hoppy, earthy, pineapple, and white grapes with a lingering, dry sour finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Refined, well-balanced, fruity, and crisp. Very well-crafted with no acidity and abundantly apparent brett and tropical notes. Great stuff!

Big thanks to Mac for sharing! Delicate, immersive aroma with layers of funky, citric complexity. Spicy and dry, funky but not overly dependent on the farmhouse.

Juicy is appropriately named; highly citric base delivers a mouthful of tangerines ready to be zapped by the microflora remnants. Dangerously close to Mimosa.

Savor each sip: there's tons to appreciate here. Brewing mastery in a bottle.

Bottle. Thanks to Chris H. Big tropical fruit aroma, along with more than a touch of manure and some oak. Clear pale straw color, light filmy head. Strong sourness in the initial, lemony with Brett notes; mid palate gets smooth and more fruit emerges; final floats away with some acid tinges and bitterness. Thin body, a bit astringent, great mouthfeel. Complex, wonderful stuff.

Bottle. Cloudy orange with fine lace. Funky, juicy nose with citrus and dry tropical fruits, oak, a bit of butter, horse blanket. Tart flavor of green apple, grass, grapefruit zest. There is a nice underlying sweetness and a very bitter finish. Very good. Not their best of this type, but still great.

Aroma: lots of lemon and grapefruit, some oak and earth, pepper, leather, some light malts, dank hops.  Pours a hazy golden/light amber color, off-white head with good retention, lots of clumpy lacing.  Flavor: dank citrus, grapefruit, lemon, funk and leather, leaves, light-medium hop bitterness, oak, white wine.  Theres a slight toasty malt character, a hint of sweetness mid-taste, then a bone dry and slightly acidic finish.  Light body, high carbonation.  Nice brew.

A cloudy golden orange pour with a tall white head. Very zesty with notes of both lemon and lime zest. A nice pepper and fruit ester quality, plenty of grapefruit, melon, and a nice citric tartness. Good dry flavor with tons of citrus. Lime zest, lemon zest, and grapefruit. Some spice notes, mild earthy funk, white pepper, green melon, and a light tartness.

Erupted as soon as I opened my bottle so I lost a quarter of it right from the start.. Appearance was  Orange with a slight haze, alot  of sediment floating around due to the eruption, big 3 finger white head.
Smell wasFunky, brett, lemon and  tart. Taste was 1st Orange, lemon,  wine and oaky  bread, and a slight tart. Not as tart as the nose would suggest.Medium mouthfeel, moderate carbonation.
Average Saison when you compare it to other HF ones. It was a gusher, have a glass ready. It is not the whale that some are suggesting it is.

Bottle shared by Corbit, thanks! Pours a slightly cloudy burnt gold with a near white head that dissipates completely. Aroma has a light pepper with horse blanket and a bit of underlying sour fruit. Flavor has green pepper and cheese with backing tart fruit.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2013 Pours unclear thick amber peach flesh in color with a beautiful bright white head. The aroma brings juicy citrus orange juice and hops blended well bringing a zesty crispiness. The flavor brings juicy orange juice influence again from the Mimosa with a bitter citrus ending from the hops on the palate.

Wow.... After being dissapointed with Ann, HF blew me away with Juicy.

Bottle poured into HF stemware.  Nice frothy white head with tight tiny bubbles.  The smell immediately hits you with a strong brett and tropical fruit presence.

This beer has incredible balance, and amazingly palatable.  

Taste is tart, green sour Apple rhind mixed with brett, pear,and slight sweetness of pineapple.

I had to pry the glass away from my wife who typically strongly dislikes "sour" beers.  Ive been telling her that mimosa would turn her into a HF junky but juicy did the trick.  Now the hunt is on to find more

Bottle split with Allen, Bill, Tim, Frank, and couple other heads at the big end of world tasting. Frank supplied this treat. Cloudy, bright, pink tinted orange pour with foamy white head. Aromas and taste of orange juice, tropical fruits and hops, flowers, brett, sour mimosa, marmalade, grapefruit zest, blood orange, tangerine, kiwi, mango, & honeydew($ melon). I mean do these guys make a beer that isnt the best of its style? If they do, I am unaware of it. Holy shit this is so amazing and deliciously hoppy/fruity. Its not really a sour ale to me but does have a little funk to it esp as it warmed up a bit. No one touches the consistency and quality of Hill Farm in the craft beer world, No One!

Slight gusher...Pours a slightly hazy rusty golden color with a few fingers of fizzy foam. On the nose its got a great base of barnyard brett, dank earthy hops, berry, tart citrus and some round barrel oak touches. On the palate its a complex balance between rustic barnyard and bright acidic vinous fruit. Amazingly good but hard to put your finger on exactly what the best part is. A true beer to ponder and sip...flavors just keep appearing. YUM

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2012 A beer reminiscent and comparable to the happy accident that was the original Cuvee de Castleton. Unique and interesting even for a beer that is probably not yet fully developed. Great beer, even if the maker leaves something to be desired.

Pours a deep dirty hazy orange with a nice off white bubbly head. Spotty lacing, and a head that dissolves to a persistent foamy ring around the edges. Aroma is very juicy; spicy, fruity hops (citrus, papaya, mangos), stinky feet, wine, oak, barnyard funk, and bacterial sour/tartness. Taste is very similar however more bitterness comes through in the taste. Definitely highly hopped or high alpha hop varieties used. Lots of citrus and vinous flavors. Tart, funky. Very nice texture to this beer, high carbonation, dry, crisp but very drinkable. I wish this were a 750ml! Overall, excellent.

375mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany), pours a cloudy, opaque deep orangey amber with a small-ish beige head. Nose brings out the wine barrels on top, with wild yeast moderately apparent that might be more potent in a few months. Flavour brings out some moderate tartness, a fairly prominent wild yeast character even though this is a young brett beer, white wine barrels, and a dry finish of hops similar to Nelson Sauvin or some other NZ variant. So much depth to this, mixing the brettanomyces and white wine barrels to utter perfection, giving off only a mild tartness. This could be classified as either a wild ale or saison. Probably my favourite farmhouse ale by Hill Farmstead so far. Wonderful.

LIVE RATE! Single 375 mL bottle purchased from the brewery yesterday noontime. Oddly enough, there was a line but it wasnt too big so I dealt; HF employees pours $5 that got you four pours. It was one helluva drive, but sincerely worth it. Pours a deeply dark orange with an eruptive, legging off-white head sitting atop. Damn sexy but nothing I havent seen before. Smells incredibly fragrant, showcasing notes of blood orange, coconut oil, dank hops, Kalamata olives, farmhouse yeasts, brief funkiness, grapefruit zest, prickly pear and daisies. I actually have to stand back, the tastes are so fascinatingly intense... okay, firstly I get dank citrus hops resembling chives and marijuana in flavor; honeydew melon, an assault of wild and Belgian yeasts, daisies, wheat malt, a tangerine/grapefruit combination, sage, lavender and burnt plastic. Starts and ends briny, flowery, citrusy and tart.

Purchased same day.  Poured into a HF glass.  Pour is an amber/pink hued color with foamy white head.  Aroma is rich melon and citrus with perfect barnyard mustyness.  Taste is perfumey citrus and great vinous notes with some light vanilla and a tart middle and dry finish.  Another huge winner from Hill Farmstead.  Damn homers and their inflated ratings! amiright...
Awesome beer, amazing lactose aroma, Great taste, the finish is of oranges Laura loves it

Pours a clear golden amber with a nice frothy white head. Eathen bretty cheesecloth, melon, cantaloupe, papya, and cherry pie in the aroma give way to doughy bready super acidic funk, huge tropical fruit character, and a strong backbone of melon. Hints of oak in the finish. The palate holds frothy prickling effervescence with a pillowy mouthfeel and uber dry finish. Reminded me a lot of the base saison character in Civil Disobedience 4.5- huge melon and tropical flavors abound. Another stellar farmhouse ale that demonstrates the unmistakable Hill Farmstead funk character while having some definite uniqueness to make it stand out against its brothers.

12oz (375ML) Bottle enjoyed in a tasting glass at room temperature on 11/14/12.

A - Cloudy muted orange appearance with a few "floaties" due to a vigorous pour. A mild 1 finger fluffy pillow-like white head that faded to a minor level of head that remained throughout the drink. 

S - The best aroma from a beer Ive ever encountered. The depth is remarkable. Overall, Brett dominates the nose. This barnyard  irrefutable  Brett aroma is unmistakable. Its present and there to impress. Hints of lemon, oranges and white wine are present as well. 

T - Tart from start to finish. Bready and Bretty throughout. Hints of grape skins, melon, cucumbers and sweet orange zest with a handful of grape skins. The tartness is so pleasurable and would be perfect on a hot summer day. Its not sour..just tart. The very common taste of Shaun Hills Saisons is easy to detect. Like Arthur, Anna and their barrel aged versions of those two saisons, this beer is very close. Perhaps most similar to a "juicy" version of Flora? Thats probably the best way to describe it. 

M - Medium body and carbonation. Exceptional balance and enjoyable now. id love to try this again in 6 months to see how it progresses. 

O - Is it the best wild ale Ive had from Shaun HIll? No. For tart characters and overall quality, Id say Mimosa, Flora and Art take the cake. However, Juicy is unique. It stands on its own and its perfect in its own way. Is it like other HFS beers? Sort of. The terroir of the Hill Farmstead is strong in this one but its unique and you cant assume its exactly like other barrel aged beers from this tiny brewery in Vermont. Its a fantastic beer and one that I wish was available in 750ML bottles. 375 is just enough to make you beg for more.
